video.title: Git and GitHub for Beginners - Crash Course
video.description:
Learn about Git and GitHub in this tutorial. These are important tools for all developers to understand. Git and GitHub make it easier to manage different software versions and make it easier for multiple people to work on the same software project.

This course was developed by Gwen Faraday. Check out her YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxA99Yr6P_tZF9_BgtMGAWA 

🔗 Git Commands: https://gist.github.com/gwenf/19e5748a5391929e8e938a22c8a4b3f2
🔗 Install git: https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/install-git
🔗 SSH Keys: https://help.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/generating-a-new-ssh-key-and-adding-it-to-the-ssh-agent


⭐️ Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) Introduction
⌨️ (1:10) What is git?
⌨️ (1:30) What is version control?
⌨️ (2:10) Terms to be learn in video
⌨️ (5:20) Git commands
⌨️ (7:05) sign up in GitHub
⌨️ (11:32) using git in local machine
⌨️ (11:54) git install
⌨️ (12:48) getting code editor
⌨️ (13:30) inside VS Code
⌨️ (14:30) cloning through VS Code
⌨️ (17:30) git commit command
⌨️ (18:15) git add command
⌨️ (19:15) committing
⌨️ (20:20) git push command
⌨️ (20:30) SSH Keys
⌨️ (25:25) git push
⌨️ (30:21) Review workflow so far
⌨️ (31:40) Compare between GitHub workflow and local git workflow
⌨️ (32:42) git branching
⌨️ (56:30) Undoing in git
⌨️ (1:01:50) Forking in git
⌨️ (1:07:55) Ending



Thanks to Harsh Raj for creating these time codes and section descriptions.



--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Alex Mondragon
topLevelComment.text:
Hey guys, if anyone see a ".DS_Store" file when you commit (with mac) , be careful! Usually this doesn't show when you have a ".gitignore" file set to ignore it in you app's folder. Probably Gwen turned off the automatic creation of this file globally in her terminal by running: defaults write com.apple.desktopservices DSDontWriteNetworkStores true

You can turn it back on by running: defaults write com.apple.desktopservices DSDontWriteNetworkStores false

Thank you so much Gwen, FCC and this amazing community!

topLevelComment.text: Great tutorial! I'd like to point out that the setup processes of the ssh-agent is Mac specific. On Linux distributions with systemd you'd use systemd/User to start ssh-agent upon login. Some distribution e.g. Ubuntu come with this service enabled by default while on others e.g. Arch Linux you have to set it up manually.

topLevelComment.author: C is for Coding
topLevelComment.text:
(0:00) Introduction
(1:10) What is git?
(1:30) What is version control?
(2:10) Terms to be learn in video
(5:20) Git commands 
(7:05) sign up in GitHub
(11:32) using git in local machine
(11:54) git install 
	<12:08> GitBash for Window OR COMMAND PROMPT
(12:48) getting code editor: VSCode
(13:30) inside VS Code
	<14:05> Pulling files from GitHub. 
(14:30) cloning through VS Code
	<14:25> Go to VSCode VIEW MENU > TERMINAL: Opens the TERMINAL and shows current folder.
	<14:48> [[command]] git clone & github folder link (from GitHub, copy link CLONE-OR-DOWNLOAD, GREEN BUTTON)
	<15:15> Moving to folder.  [[command]] cd <nameOfFolder>
	<15:27> Indication that we are in GIT repository.  There is a hidden folder.  (dotgitdirectory)
	<16:20> [[command]] ls-la (list everything in directory including hidden directories. ls-la if not in MAC.
	<16:45> .git file (blue text) - this saves all changes made to repository.
	<17:15> Changing and updating / saving files.  
(17:30) [[command git commit]]
	<17:35> [[command git status]]: Gets status; 
(18:15) [[command git add]]
	<18:23> [[command tracking changes]] two ways of doing this
(19:15) committing     *** MUST INCLUDE DESCRIPTION ***
(20:20) [[command git push]] to push files to git
(20:30) SSH Keys
	<21:45> Search for KEY.	
	<22:47> [[command ~cat testkey.pub]]  to print the key
	<23:00> To copy key.
	<23.43> Go to GitHub
	<24:15>	Make sure local SSH command line knows that this key was generated.
	<24:25> Adding SSH key to the ssh-agent
		<24:45> Adding location of file (on console): ~vim ~/..ssh/config
(25:25) git push
	<26:28> To start a REPO locally:
(30:21) Review workflow so far: 
(31:40) Compare between GitHub workflow and local git workflow
(32:42) git branching
	<36:15> FullScreenTerminal (same as VSCode)
	<36:55> 
	<39:45> In VSCode - 'M' next to the file name means it has been modified, but not updated to GITHUB.
	<40:54> Merging 
	<43:25> PULL REQUEST (PR): Request to have code pulled onto other branch.
	<44:28> How to go to the URL
		<44:30>	URL via GITHUB interface.
			<44:50> Compare a pull-request
			<45:18> Adding Description to code being pulled in.
			<45:42> CREATE-PULL-REQUEST
				<45:45>	Interface: See comments/ add comments/ Commits/ Files Changed
				<46:15> Add comments to code
			<47:00> Merge PR
				<47:02> Resolve Conservation - needs to be done before you can merge
		<47:30> Code TAB
	<47:45> Locally: 
		<47:48> To switch to master branch 
		<47:57> Pulling changes to local environment
	<48:30> Deleting a featureBranch
	<49:06> Merge Conflicts: When multiple writing multiple files.
		<49:50> 
		<50:00>
			<50:26> 
		<50:35> Go to terminal - 
			<51:40> go to VSCode to see what is shown.
			<52:06>
		<52:42> Stashing - beyond scope of this tutorial
		<53:05> Commit    	*** MUST INCLUDE DESCRIPTION ***
			<53:05> [[git status first]]
			<53:08> [[git commit -am "commit message"]]  
				** shorthand syntax **
			<53:21> [[git checkout quick-test (branch)]] 
			<53:32> [[git diff master]] ** Check difference - this shows the changes
		<53:38> Merge
		<53:50> Master gets updated as you work; 
		<54:35> Merge Conflict
			<54:45> Interface (like GitHub) give you ways to fix it.
			<54:52>	Easiest way to fix merge conflicts is directly in your code (i.e. VSCode).
			<55:05> VSCode will give you buttons: Example accept changes; or you can do it manually.
		<55:50> Go back to Terminal
			<56:00> Need to make a commit because we have fixed the merge conflicts.
			<56:05> [[git commit -am "updated with master"]]
(56:30) Undoing in git
	<56:45> In VSCode made error.
	<56:55> Terminal
	<57:20> GIT RESET
	<57:42> [[command git status]]
	<57:50> UNDO A COMMIT	
		<57:51> 
	<59:09> If you have many different commits, 
	<59:29> LOG OF COMMITS: You can see a log of all your commits.  
	<01:00:00> Copying HASH to go to a specific commit.
		<01:00:25> [[command git reset HASHoftheCOMMIT10018709487301987410]]
		<01:00:35> VSCode - changes are still there - but not saved to GIT, or staged to GIT any longer.
		<01:00:50> What if testing and want to delete after a few commits.

(1:01:50) Forking in git
	(1:03:40) Working on larger projects - create multiple branches - master, staging, dev.
	(1:04:32) To get changes from my fork to main repository create PULL REQUEST
	(1:05:18) To merge fork within my fork.
 	(1:06:14) After merging a branch - we could delete branch from GITHUB and local machine.  

(1:07:55) Ending

topLevelComment.author: BrennanKill
topLevelComment.text:
I'm having a very challenging issue at the "create a local dir then connect it to a remote Github dir" step of this video. My github account was created pre-2020 so I believe I'm having issues with branches. Basically; when I created the demo-repo2 local directory everything was working fine until I got to the 'git push -u origin main' step. I was getting an error basically saying main was undefined or something along those lines. I tried using 'git push -u origin master' and it successfully pushed it according to CLI. If I check git status it shows no changes available.

HOWEVER - When I go to that repository on github it still shows as an empty repository; the changes are not appearing to push there. I ran 'git branch' from the demo-repo2 folder on my local vscode client and it shows 'master' as the branch. When I do the same from the 'demo-repo' dir I created earlier in the video it shows 'main' as the branch... so I've managed to end up with a main and master branch, and I don't know how to correct this issue. Any help would be appreciated. Thanks

replies.author: BrennanKill
replies.text:
I did some further testing and confirmed additional local directories I created were all defaulting to 'master' when I ran the git init command. I don't know why git would default to that and github would default to main (maybe I missed something during the git installation?), but for anyone else who might run into this problem run the following command to change the git default branch to main: 
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

I deleted the local directories that had been initialized to master and tested with a new directory and it properly initialized to the main branch and I was able to complete the push step with those commits showing in github.

topLevelComment.author: icono __
topLevelComment.text:
I feel so relived; I'm finally learning this darn thing! Thank you for the tutorial. Thank you for taking the time to do this Gwen!

Edit: Upon reviewing the tutorial again, I'd like to say:

1. When creating a tutorial, you guys should _truly_ understand the importance of slowing down to the pace of the learner. In the beginning you walk us through a nice set of key terms (which was exceptional), then start mixing lots of advanced and beginner-level concepts together in your explanations, confusing the person that's watching the video. Slow down, explain like we're 5, that's why we're here.

2. To expand upon the issue of mixing things up I mentioned above, it's okay to keep a tutorial short, and add footnotes later if you think that the advanced concepts you're touching on are still worth being aware of. That way, the beginner can truly focus their attention on the basics, and then access the footnote only when they feel comfortable with the knowledge they've acquired thus far, making the content of your footnotes even more effective. After all, isn't good programming about being efficient? 

I used to get annoyed at being expected to take additional English classes as a Computer Science student, but now I understand why. I spent 4 hours yesterday debugging a Terminal issue, only to later realize that there was an "issue" because the person who created the how-to GitHub document instructed the reader to paste this code into the Terminal command line: 

*eval "$(ssh-agent exec -s)"*

They said to *paste* this command in the terminal (meaning: include the quotation marks). After 4 hours of learning about chmod, File Links, Groups, root directory, Inodes—things I knew NOTHING about prior to this, I resolved my problem by simply removing the quotation marks. 

Now, the arrogant developer might say, "Well that's obvious". No it's not! The person said "paste", meaning I would: 

- Select the piece of code
- Apply ctrl+c to it, for Windows (cmd+c on Mac)
- Go to the Terminal and apply ctrl+v/cmd+v

Either the tutorial should have been made like this: 

*eval $(ssh-agent exec -s)* ,  

or the person writing the document should I mentioned that the quotation marks need to be removed. 

As Software Engineering becomes more collaborative, programmers can no longer get away with being asocial, and communication impaired, so this is an area a lot more engineers need to start being proficient in .

topLevelComment.author: Ana Cosic
topLevelComment.text:
git clone command throwing error message:
"git is not recognized as an internal or external command"

So I followed instruction from stackoverflow - to correctly set PATH in Windows 10 to point at Git installation:

1. Go to My Computer => Local Disk(C:) => Program Files => Git => cmd
2. Right Click the git => Select Properties and copy cmd path location
3. Come back and in the Start Menu or taskbar search, search for "environment variable".
4. Select "Edit the system environment variables".
5. Click the "Environment Variables" button at the bottom.
6. Double-click the "Path" entry under "System variables".
7. With the "New" button in the PATH editor, add previously copied CMD path to the end of the list.
8. Press OK
9. Close and re-open your command prompt.


Easy way to avoid messing with PATH variables in the first place is to re-install Git 
and select "Use Git from the Windows Command Prompt" 
(NOT "Use Git from Git Bash only")

topLevelComment.author: Michael Reeves
topLevelComment.text: Private keys don't generate public keys.  They are mathematically related to each other at creation.  It is extremely difficult to determine the mathmatical relationship, as that seed is destroyed during key creation; however, if you have both keys it is simple to solve.  The simplest explanation that everyone can understand is "You can only read messages encrypted with one key using the other key.  Because everyone has access to the public key, everyone can read messages encrypted with the private key.  Conversely, a message encrypted using the public key can only be read by someone who has the private key.  That's why it is critical to keep private keys secure."

Time: 16:40
la is just an alias as it would be defined on any UNIX like operation system... If you want it... type on the cli:   alias la='ls -la' 

And add this line in your .bashrc file and make sure each time you login the .bashrc file is loaded from .bash_profile... in .bash_profile just add...   

if [ -f .bashrc ]
then 
          . .bashrc
fi

topLevelComment.author: Andres Yesid Moreno Villa
topLevelComment.text:
Heads up for anyone doing the step shown in 29:36 (git push origin master). Aside from the fact that (as of the date that I'm writting this) "master" has been renamed to "main", in order to push from a local repository to github, an extra step has been added. It looks like one must now specify (explicitly) on which branch it's located (in this case "main"). So, now, the total steps to follow, for this particular case, would be:

git remote add origin git@github.com:Username/Repository_Name.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

Otherwise (at least in my case) an error appears. With that extra line of code it works fine.

topLevelComment.author: itsthatsquirrel
topLevelComment.text:
Windows users using VS Code might have their default terminal set to powershell and might have trouble showing hidden folders, like at 16:00. However, command prompt or git bash will allow you to show hidden folders. One way that I did this is by changing the default terminal in VS Code to command prompt. In terminal view, click on the drop down menu and click on "Select Default shell" then choose "Command Prompt" or "Git Bash".

You can add the following code to your settings.json file: "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "cmd.exe". This will make the default terminal command prompt. If using the command prompt, you can show all visible and hidden files or folders with the command following: dir /a

topLevelComment.author: Panama Fred
topLevelComment.text: When you said CD = Change Directory, I went into a time warp. I bought my first PC in 1984. It had a massive 10 meg hard drive! I knew absolutely nothing about computers. Didn't even know anyone who had one. The computer came with a thick three-ring binder with the title, DOS. I read and reread and reread the entire book until it started to make sense. (The first version of Windows didn't come out until 1985.) In 1985, I bought an early copy of Symantec's Q&A, a (non-Windows) word processor, flat file, and report generator, which relied heavily on keystroke combinations to get things done but was hinting at a graphical interface. I ran a non-profit for many years with Q&A and loved it, such an improvement from WordStar. So, now at 72-years-old, to see CD = Change Directory, I say to myself, "Hey, I can do this." Thanks for a good tutorial.

topLevelComment.author: The best copmuter programmer
topLevelComment.text:
Really love this git and github intro course, it really touches a lot of things.
1. How to create a repo locally through the CLI(Command Line Interface) or directly from GITHUB
2. git flow by using the most common commands: git add - git commit and git push/git pull, all of them with their corresponding explanation. What "origin", "remote" and "master" mean.
3. git branching: all the commands involve in that kind of operation as well as best practices.
4. git merging: when we use a "feature" branch and it's time to merge to the "master" branch  -- PR (Pull Request) on the Github side
5. How to deal with "conflicts" when merging.
6. Undoing in git: undoing from the stage area versus undoing if we have committed once or several times.
7. Understanding how and why we fork a repo on github.


Really awesome content, thank a lot for such a valuable content.

replies.author: Bethel Hall
replies.text: An SSH key is an alternate way to identify yourself that doesn't require you to enter you username and password every time. SSH keys come in pairs, a public key that gets shared with services like GitHub, and a private key that is stored only on your computer. If the keys match, you're granted access.
